results.abstract: Michiko Kakutani reviews book Emporium: Stories by Adam Johnson; photo (M)

headline.main: An Out-of-Kilter World, Just Down the Interstate

results.snippet: EMPORIUM  Stories  By Adam Johnson  246 pages. Viking. $24.95.       Adam Johnson's funny-sad-bizarre stories take place in a world located somewhere between Kurt Vonnegut's sci-fi empire and that wild and crazy land of weirdos limned in T....
results.lead_paragraph: EMPORIUM Stories By Adam Johnson 246 pages. Viking. $24.95. Adam Johnson's funny-sad-bizarre stories take place in a world located somewhere between Kurt Vonnegut's sci-fi empire and that wild and crazy land of weirdos limned in T. Coraghessan Boyle's stories. It's a place where strange things happen and stranger things threaten to occur; a place recognizable, in its lineaments, from our present-day reality, but exaggerated, italicized or stretched to the point of distortion like Silly Putty. In ''Trauma Plate,'' the daughter of entrepreneurs who own a bullet-proof-vest rental shop asks her boyfriend to take a shot at her Kevlar-protected chest. In ''The Canadanaut,'' a top-secret group of misfit scientists, hidden away in the snowbound reaches of northern Canada, scheme to send a diminutive fur trapper to the Moon. And in ''Teen Sniper,'' a 15-year-old boy works as a police sniper in Silicon Valley, taking down the demented and the delusional, who have been taking hostages at software companies.

results.abstract: Astronauts floating over International Space Station attach 44-foot truss as base for orbiting outpost; photo (S)

headline.main: Major Component of Space Station Is Attached

results.snippet: Astronauts floating over the International Space Station attached a 44-foot truss today that will serve as the base of a new backbone for the orbiting outpost.    The 27,000-pound beam, crammed with wiring and conduits, is the first of seven segments...
results.lead_paragraph: Astronauts floating over the International Space Station attached a 44-foot truss today that will serve as the base of a new backbone for the orbiting outpost. The 27,000-pound beam, crammed with wiring and conduits, is the first of seven segments that will eventually become a 356-foot spine for the station that will support four giant solar power arrays, heat radiators and new laboratory modules.

results.abstract: Sean O'Keefe, new administrator of NASA, outlines a modest vision for NASA of future, saying that it will concentrate on research and education--including finally sending schoolteacher into space in 2004; asserts agency needs to return to its fundamentals as research agency, emphasizing development of technology that could improve space exploration or promote national security; photo (M)

headline.main: NASA Says 2004 Mission Will Include Schoolteacher

results.snippet: Outlining a modest vision for the NASA of the future, the space agency's new administrator said yesterday that it would concentrate on research and education -- including finally sending a schoolteacher into space in 2004.    Sean O'Keefe, who took...
results.lead_paragraph: Outlining a modest vision for the NASA of the future, the space agency's new administrator said yesterday that it would concentrate on research and education -- including finally sending a schoolteacher into space in 2004. Sean O'Keefe, who took over as director of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration in December, said the agency needed to return to its fundamentals as a research agency, emphasizing the development of technology that could improve space exploration or promote national security. He called for more science-based exploration of the solar system and for inspiring future scientists and explorers through an education initiative.

results.abstract: Dave Kehr reviews Imax movie Space Station 3-D, directed by Toni Myers (M)
results.snippet: Directed by Toni Myers  Not rated, 47 minutes      ''Space Station 3-D,'' the latest film to be photographed for the giant-screen Imax process in three dimensions, is apparently narrated by Tom Cruise. At least, that's what the credits say, though...
results.lead_paragraph: Directed by Toni Myers Not rated, 47 minutes ''Space Station 3-D,'' the latest film to be photographed for the giant-screen Imax process in three dimensions, is apparently narrated by Tom Cruise. At least, that's what the credits say, though the images are so overwhelming that it's hard for a viewer to recollect very much of what Mr. Cruise says or how he says it.

results.abstract: Dave Kehr reviews animiated movie Mutant Aliens, directed by Bill Plympton (M)
results.snippet: Directed by Bill Plympton  Not rated, 83 minutes      It is hard not to admire Bill Plympton, the maverick animator whose distinctive pencil-sketch style has graced a host of short films, commercials, MTV spots and three full-length animated...
results.lead_paragraph: Directed by Bill Plympton Not rated, 83 minutes It is hard not to admire Bill Plympton, the maverick animator whose distinctive pencil-sketch style has graced a host of short films, commercials, MTV spots and three full-length animated features, including his latest work, ''Mutant Aliens.''

results.abstract: Space shuttle Atlantis lands at Kennedy Space Center, Cape Canaveral, Fla, finishing ambitious mission to mount $600 million girder and $190 million rail cart at International Space Station; Lt Col Michael J Bloomfield, mission's commander, lands craft; photo (M)

headline.main: Shuttle Glides Home After Ambitious Mission

results.snippet: The space shuttle Atlantis glided to a tire-smoking touchdown today at Kennedy Space Center, finishing an ambitious mission to mount a $600 million girder and a $190 million rail cart at the International Space Station.    Skirting puffy white clouds...
results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Atlantis glided to a tire-smoking touchdown today at Kennedy Space Center, finishing an ambitious mission to mount a $600 million girder and a $190 million rail cart at the International Space Station. Skirting puffy white clouds in otherwise clear blue skies, Lt. Col. Michael J. Bloomfield of the Air Force landed the shuttle at 12:27 p.m., about four minutes after its signature twin sonic booms signaled its impending arrival.

results.abstract: Matthew Gurewitsch article on new Imax 3D movie Space Station 3D, directed by Toni Myers and filmed by International Space Station crew members using special scaled-down cameras; photo (M)

headline.main: Is That a Space Helmet Or Just Your 3D Goggles?

results.snippet: THE Canadian filmmaker Toni Myers was enjoying some much-needed R & R when her cell phone rang. Colonel James S. Voss was checking in from the International Space Station with a surprising development: ''I've shot six seconds of aliens!,'' he...
results.lead_paragraph: THE Canadian filmmaker Toni Myers was enjoying some much-needed R & R when her cell phone rang. Colonel James S. Voss was checking in from the International Space Station with a surprising development: ''I've shot six seconds of aliens!,'' he announced from 220 miles above earth. Aliens? As producer and director of ''Space Station 3D,'' the new large-format 3D release from Imax, Ms. Myers had developed an advance ''shopping list'' of set-ups and situations, and aliens were no part of the scenario. The project was documentary in character and proud of it. Still, Ms. Myers had encouraged the orbiting crew members to contribute their own suggestions. Col. Voss's extraterrestrials, she learned much later, were stowaways from the ground: children's toys, cool totems of home, hanging out happily in zero-G.

results.abstract: Mark Shuttleworth, South African millionaire who has dreamed of rockets and space since boyhood, will become world's second space tourist when he blasts off in Russian Soyuz spacecraft, bound for International Space Station; Shuttleworth reportedly will pay more than $18- to $20-million spent by Dennis Tito (S)

headline.main: A South African With a Dream Ready for Launch Into Space

results.snippet: A South African millionaire who has dreamed of rockets and space flight since he was a boy is to become the world's second space tourist on Thursday when he blasts off in a Russian Soyuz spacecraft bound for the International Space Station.    The...
results.lead_paragraph: A South African millionaire who has dreamed of rockets and space flight since he was a boy is to become the world's second space tourist on Thursday when he blasts off in a Russian Soyuz spacecraft bound for the International Space Station. The 28-year-old millionaire, Mark Shuttleworth, has gone through months of tests and training in Russia to become part of the three-member crew aboard a taxi flight to bring a fresh Soyuz to the station. The Soyuz, which serves as an emergency lifeboat, is replaced twice a year.

results.abstract: Mark Shuttleworth, South African millionaire, boards International Space Station from Russian Soyuz spacecraft as world's second space tourist; reportedly paid $20 million for trip; photo (M)

headline.main: Line Forms to Be the Next Space Tourist

results.snippet: As Mark Shuttleworth, a South African millionaire, prepared to take up residence on the International Space Station as the world's second space tourist, a line formed to be the next such visitor.    The candidates for the next tourist seat on a...
results.lead_paragraph: As Mark Shuttleworth, a South African millionaire, prepared to take up residence on the International Space Station as the world's second space tourist, a line formed to be the next such visitor. The candidates for the next tourist seat on a Russian flight to the station in October or November include a member of the pop music group 'N Sync, a woman who calls herself a soccer mom and a wealthy Polish businessman.

results.abstract: Ruth Handler, creator of Barbie Doll, dies at age 85; pioneering creation in 1959 became one of world's best-selling toys and transformed sleepy Mattel Inc, which she co-founded with husband, into postwar success story; Barbie has been icon of American popular culture, as well as artistic muse and lightning rod of feminist politics; photos (M)

headline.main: Ruth Handler, Whose Barbie Gave Dolls Curves, Dies at 85

results.snippet: Ruth Handler, creator of the Barbie doll, one of the world's best-selling toys and one that became an icon of American popular culture, an artistic muse and a lightning rod of feminist politics, died on Saturday at a hospital in Los Angeles, where...
results.lead_paragraph: Ruth Handler, creator of the Barbie doll, one of the world's best-selling toys and one that became an icon of American popular culture, an artistic muse and a lightning rod of feminist politics, died on Saturday at a hospital in Los Angeles, where she lived. She was 85. Mrs. Handler experienced complications after having colon surgery several months ago, said her husband, Elliot.
